image.altText: Composite image of young girl and police members and a search dog.

title.children: Australia's biggest home builder tells some customers to pay higher prices or risk losing their new homes and deposits

image.altText: Sinead O'connor wearing a priests black outfit with a cross holding a microphone and smiling

items.synopsis: Irish singer-songwriter Sinéad O'Connor, who became a superstar in her mid-20s, dies at 56.

title.children: Sinéad O'Connor, who topped charts in the 90s, dies aged 56

image.altText: Two Australian female swimmers stand on the medal podium at the World Aquatics Championships.

items.synopsis: At just 19, Mollie O'Callaghan writes herself into the record books at the World Aquatics Championships in Fukuoka, winning gold ahead of Australian teammate Ariarne Titmus in the women's 200 metres freestyle.

title.children: Aussie O'Callaghan stunned after breaking long-standing swimming world record

image.altText: Riders on a mountain bike trail through a forest.

items.synopsis: Dorset Council, in Tasmania's north-east, is being warned it may be suspended after allegations of conflicts of interest, poor governance and disrespect for community members.

title.children: Tasmanian council facing suspension as minister appoints board of inquiry

image.altText: A woman in a green top stands against a stone wall.

items.synopsis: Sarab was 11 when ISIS militants attacked her village and sold her into slavery. Five years later, she had been given to six different men. Now, she wants justice, writes Stephanie March.

title.children: Abducted and sold into slavery at 11, now Sarab wants justice

image.altText: A composite image of Kevin Spacey clutching an Oscar and a court sketch

image.altText: Former Chinese foreign minister Qin Gang scratches his left eyebrow with his left hand as he looks down through spectacles.

items.synopsis: China's youngest ever minister went on to become the country's shortest-serving foreign minister, lasting only 207 days before vanishing for a month and eventually having everything he had done in office removed from the government's records, writes Bang Xiao.

title.children: 'A very urgent removal': Qin Gang was favoured by Xi but ended up China's shortest-serving foreign minister

image.altText: Bald man in army greens holding a gun in front of white wall.

items.synopsis: One of the top leaders in the Russian Army, Sergei Surovikin, has not been seen since the mutiny against the Kremlin last month. At first it seems odd, but it turns out General Surovikin is not who he seems.

title.children: Russian 'General Armageddon' Sergei Surovikin is missing — is he 'resting' or Resting In Peace?

image.altText: A man in a white t-shirt standing in a fiery wreckage

title.children: As the fire advanced, Kyriakos fled to a Greek beach. There, he was met with apocalyptic scenes

title.children: As EVs take over, the resale value of petrol and diesel cars is set to fall. Here's when it will hit

title.children: South Korea to build fighting vehicles for Australian Army under $6 billion contract

image.altText: An Ireland player smiles and stands with arms wide acknowledging the crowd after scoring a goal at the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Five quick hits — Ireland score an 'Olimpico' and an Argentinian player takes heat for a CR7 tattoo

image.altText: A close up shot of Kevin Spacey in glasses

items.synopsis: The Oscar-winning actor broke down in tears when the jury in London found him not guilty of nine sexual offence charges.

title.children: 'Thank you, thank you': Actor Kevin Spacey found not guilty of sexual offences in London

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo, a woman with blonde hair and blue eyes, looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Legal experts have called for the evidence collected by the special investigative office set up to investigate the Lawyer X scandal to be referred to an interstate prosecutor, saying lack of transparency could give rise to questions about perceived conflict of interest.

title.children: Legal experts call for Lawyer X evidence to be referred to an interstate prosecutor

image.altText: An older man in navy suit with bright blue tie stands next to young man in formal military uniform

items.synopsis: Hun Sen has ruled Cambodia for almost 40 years. Now, he is handing power to his son.

title.children: The mysterious billionaire son of Cambodia's autocratic ruler is poised to take power

image.altText: Chalmers points in front of his face. He's standing in front of flags.

items.synopsis: After this week's encouraging inflation figures, the task for the government now is to convince the electorate of two things: cost-of-living pressures will continue easing and it's not just thanks to the Reserve Bank, writes David Speers.

title.children: Inflation may be easing but the political arm-wrestle over the cost of living goes on

image.altText: A young woman stands outside in front of a tree, looking into camera with a serious expression.

items.synopsis: Australia's largest oil and gas company, Woodside Energy, threatens to sue individual activists for financial damages it claims to have suffered in a recent protest, leading to accusations it is trying to shut down environmental activism.

title.children: Woodside threatens to sue climate activists over stink-bomb protest

image.altText: A man in a wetsuit checks on a whale stranded on the beach

items.synopsis: Scientists hope footage of pilot whales captured prior to this week's mass stranding on Western Australia's south coast could provide insights into the animals' behaviour.

title.children: Why do whales beach themselves? Scientists hope mass stranding in WA could provide answers

image.altText: Jerome Powell stands at a podium behind a wall of American flags.

items.synopsis: US stocks finish flat as the Federal Reserve hikes interest rates to a 22-year high. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Fed 'prepared to raise further' as rates hit 22-year high, ASX set for flat start

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A few interesting snippets out of US Fed chair Jerome Powell's press conference, as noted by NAB's head of market economics Tapas Strickland. A key takeaway is that the Fed's staff are no longer forecasting a recession, expecting inflation to come down without a huge jump in unemployment or an economic contraction. However, that forecast is not based on a prediction that interest rates will soon be lowered. "We think we're going to need to hold, certainly, policy at restrictive levels for some time, and we'd be prepared to raise further if we think that's appropriate," Mr Powell told reporters. For traders optimistically expecting a swathe of rate cuts next year, Mr Powell played down the odds. "Many people wrote down rate cuts for next year," he said. "I think the median was several, for next year, and that's going to be a judgment that we have to make then, a full year from now." However, traders seemed to largely ignore that comment. " Markets continue to price around a 40 per cent chance of a follow up hike by November, though pricing of cuts extended with 136bps [basis points] of cuts thereafter by end of 2024 (up from 130bps yesterday)," wrote Mr Strickland. A constant theme through Powell's presser was that the Fed's decisions are going to be driven by the latest data more than its forecasts. This is what he said about the Fed's next meeting. "We're going to look at two additional job reports, two additional CPI reports, lots of activity data. That's what we're going to look at, and we're going to make that decision then," he told journalists. "That decision could mean another hike in September or it could mean that we decide to maintain at that level ." Can't get a much clearer message than that — forget your forecasts and look at the latest numbers people.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fed no longer forecasting a US recession as soft landing optimism grows

children.content: A few interesting snippets out of
US Fed chair Jerome Powell's press conference
, as noted by
NAB's head of market economics Tapas Strickland
A key takeaway is that the Fed's staff are
no longer forecasting a recession
, expecting inflation to come down without a huge jump in unemployment or an economic contraction.
However, that forecast is not based on a prediction that interest rates will soon be lowered.
"We think we're going to need to hold, certainly, policy at
restrictive levels for some time
, and we'd be
prepared to raise further
if we think that's appropriate," Mr Powell told reporters.
For traders optimistically expecting a swathe of rate cuts next year, Mr Powell played down the odds.
"Many people wrote down rate cuts for next year," he said.
"I think the median was several, for next year, and that's going to be a judgment that we have to make then, a full year from now."
However, traders seemed to largely ignore that comment.
Markets continue to price around a 40 per cent chance of a follow up hike by November
, though pricing of cuts extended with 136bps [basis points] of cuts thereafter by end of 2024 (up from 130bps yesterday)," wrote Mr Strickland.
A constant theme through Powell's presser was that the Fed's decisions are going to be driven by the latest data more than its forecasts.
This is what he said about the Fed's next meeting.

"We're going to look at two additional job reports, two additional CPI reports, lots of activity data. That's what we're going to look at, and we're going to make that decision then," he told journalists.
"That decision
could mean another hike in September or it could mean that we decide to maintain at that level
Can't get a much clearer message than that — forget your forecasts and look at the latest numbers people.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Fed's decision to raise rates by 0.25 percentage points to 5.25-5.5% surprised no-one, nor did its guidance that the future of interest rates is data dependent. That meant that the decision and Jerome Powell's press conference had little effect on Wall Street, which finished about as flat as it can. The benchmark S & P 500 index finished down less than one point to 4,567 points, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%. "The message for the market was that it didn't move the needle," Angelo Kourfafas, investment strategist at Edward Jones, told Reuters. "There's always a fear of a big surprise."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street finishes flat as the Fed delivers no surprises

children.content: The Fed's decision to raise rates by 0.25 percentage points to 5.25-5.5% surprised no-one, nor did its guidance that the future of interest rates is data dependent.
That meant that the decision and Jerome Powell's press conference had little effect on Wall Street, which finished about as flat as it can.
The benchmark S
P 500 index finished down less than one point to 4,567 points, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%.
"The message for the market was that it didn't move the needle," Angelo Kourfafas, investment strategist at Edward Jones, told Reuters.
"There's always a fear of a big surprise."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, I'll be with you for the blog this morning and joined by Sue Lannin and Rachel Pupazzoni later in the day. The big news overnight was the US Federal Reserve rates decision. There were no surprises, with the Fed lifting its benchmark overnight funds rate to between 5.25 and 5.5%. The mid-point of that range is the highest cash rate in the US since early 2001. Fed chair Jerome Powell left open the possibility of another rate hike next month, while also playing down the prospect of any rate cuts in the short term. "It's certainly possible that we will raise funds again at the September meeting if the data warranted," he told reporters. "I would also say it's possible that we would choose to hold steady and we're going to be making careful assessments, as I said, meeting by meeting." Financial markets are currently pricing in around an 80 per cent chance the Fed holds rates steady next month, according to Refinitiv data, amid signs US inflation is slowing quite quickly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The US Fed hikes rates again to reach a 22-year high

"I would also say it's possible that we would choose to hold steady and we're going to be making careful assessments, as I said, meeting by meeting."
Financial markets are currently pricing in around
an 80 per cent chance the Fed holds rates steady next month
, according to Refinitiv data, amid signs US inflation is slowing quite quickly.
